did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Civic Interests, Series D

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records are arranged by subject matter in 27 series. Most of these series are wholly or partially open for research. The series are:

A John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; C Business Interests; D Civic Interests; E Cultural Interests; F Economic Reform Interests; G Educational Interests; H Friends and Services; I Homes; J Housing Interests; K Medical Interests; L Real Estate; M Maps and Memorabilia; N Religious Interests; O Rockefeller Boards; P Welfare - General Files; Q World Affairs; R Welfare - Youth Files; S Documents; T Public Relations; U Public Land Law Review Commission; V Greenrock; W Properties; X Costume Collection; Y Media; Z John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal; AA Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; AC Abby Rockefeller Mauz√©

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The central figure in the creation and operation of the Standard Oil Company during its rise to the top of the petroleum industry, John D. Rockefeller (JDR) established for the family a leading role in business and philanthropy. From the days of his earliest employment, Rockefeller, a devout Baptist, was generous in his giving to worthy causes, especially those of a religious nature. During the 1890s he developed an orderly system of philanthropic giving through an office staff that included his close advisor, Frederick T. Gates (1853-1929) and his son, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960). With the advise of these and other associates, Rockefeller established the University of Chicago, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now The Rockefeller University), the Rockefeller Foundation, and other philanthropic organizations working nationally and internationally in the fields of education, religion, and health. Rockefeller's total donations to philanthropic endeavors are estimated to have been $540 million.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (JDR Jr.) joined his father's office on October 1, 1897. He oversaw the expansion and diversification of the philanthropic work begun by his father. During his lifetime, the younger Rockefeller gave more than $537 million to educational, religious, cultural, medical, and other charitable projects.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1874-1948), passed the Rockefeller philanthropic impulse on to their children. John D. 3rd (1906-1978), Nelson A. (1908-1979), Laurance S. (1910-2004), Winthrop (1912-1973), and David (1915-) further expanded and diversified Rockefeller influence and interests, establishing their own philanthropic organizations, most notably the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1940), and becoming more active politically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) materials document the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons, John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David, into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office.

This material contains correspondence, reports, pamphlets, memoranda, deeds, maps, contracts, reports, minutes, charters, certificates of incorporation, clippings, diaries, notebooks, calendars, and memorabilia.
There is a microfilm card index of personal and institutional names.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in multiple sections, generally in alphabetical order:

American Institute of Criminal Law and Criminology; Association of the Bar; Bureau of Municipal Research; Citizens Union of the City of New York; Citizens Budget Commission; Civic Leagues; Civil Service Reform Association; National Civil Service League; Constitutional League of America; Democracy; Fire Companies; Grand Army of the Republic; Highways; Juries; League of Women Voters; Mayor's Committee; New York City and New York State; People's Institute; Pocantico Hills (NY) Lyceum; Hope Chapel Community House, Tarrytown (NY); Police; Political Organizations; Russell Sage Foundation; Regional Planning Association Research; Tarrytown (NY) Projects; United States Government; Westchester County (NY) Charter; Westchester County (NY) Research Bureau; Westchester County (NY) Organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series reflects primarily the activities of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., but significant documentation on the political and civic concerns of each of his sons is also present. In addition to extensive files on family support of the Republican Party on the national, state, and local level, separate folders exist on specific candidates, such as President Dwight D. Eisenhower, New York City Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, and New York Governor Thomas Dewey. There are substantial files on family support for Nelson Rockefeller during his first gubernatorial campaign and immediately afterward. However, very little material exists in this series on his presidential effort in 1960.

The files on Rockefeller involvement with "good" government groups is, from an historical point of view, at least as significant as the political files. Organizations such as the Bureau of Municipal Research and the National Civic Federation provided the personnel and the theoretical underpinnings for the revolution in government which occurred during the course of the twentieth century. Rockefeller involvement with these groups through the end of the 1950s is well documented in this series.

Civic involvement of a different nature is also to be found in this series. The family's concern for an involvement with the problems and organizations of Tarrytown, Westchester County, and New York City constitute a large portion of this series. These are primarily relationships with local fire departments, grand juries, transportation departments, and police.

Finally, Nelson Rockefeller's service in the administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Dwight D. Eisenhower, and John D. Rockefeller 3rd's participation in the Japanese Peace Treaty negotiations in 1951 are included in this series.

did.unittitle: American Institute of Criminal Law and Criminology
American Institute of Criminal Law and Criminology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some reports on work of Institute. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. pledges $10,000, paid. J. B. Reynolds real spirit of institute, died in 1923 - John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s connection ceased. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., James Bronson, Raymond B. Fosdick.

did.unittitle: Association of the Bar
Association of the Bar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests for endowment declined. Work of association. Thomas M. Debevoise's membership. John D. Rockefeller 3rd made contributions toward study to improve administration of justice in New York in 1953. Other gifts. Papers prepared for the Association by New York attorneys. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, John E. Lockwood, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Association of the Bar - Laurance S. Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller gives $20,000 toward study of justice with respect to problems of the family. Study panel urges single city court for family cases. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's contribution toward Court Revision Activities Gellhorn study. Public interest through play "The Maze. Laurance S. Rockefeller gift, Socony Mobil Oil stock. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, John E. Lockwood, Allen T. Klots, Edwin T. Chinlund, D. B. Bonsal.

did.unittitle: Association of the Bar - Mayors Committee on the Courts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller member of committee. Chairman of subcommittee on Youth, Family and Children's Matters. Left committee in 1959. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Allen T. Klots.

did.unittitle: Association of the Bar - Children and Families in the Courts - Volume I

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report to the Special Committee to Study the Administration of Law Relating to the Family, Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Report prepared by Walter Gellhorn, assisted by Jacob D. Hyman and Sidney H. Asch. Report was for committee use only and was not published.

did.unittitle: Association of the Bar - Children and Families in the Courts - Volume II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report to the Special Committee to Study the Administration of Law Relating to the Family, Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Report prepared by Walter Gellhorn, assisted by Jacob D. Hyman and Sidney H. Asch. Report was for committee use only and was not published.

Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, W. Allen, Jerome Greene, J. Dewey, J. P. Mitchel.

did.unittitle: Citizens Union of the City of New York
Citizens Union of the City of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Began as union of anti-Tammany element, modified to straight good government program. Election struggle, 1913. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made $100 annual contributions, later increased to $200, $300, plus special gifts. $400 annual gifts in 1930s for all purposes. Rockefeller staff supported idea, did not initiate anything. In 1940s, Union moved toward city planning, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest declined. Requests for contributions. Discussion of program. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Nelson A. Rockefeller made small annual contributions. Invitations to dinners declined. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, Willard S. Richardson, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dana S. Creel, Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

Citizens Budget Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Rockefeller, Jr.'s yearly contributions. Membership list. Plaque offered to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. John D. Rockefeller 3rd gets award. de V. O. Smith comment. Correspondents include Jay Downer, Arthur W. Packard, Thomas M. Debevoise, Yorke Allen, Robert W. Dowling, de V. O. Smith, A. D. Leidesdorf, John M. Leavens, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: National Civil Service League
National Civil Service League

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Objective was to gain business-like administration of government through a well qualified civil service. Nominal Rockefeller interest in work of League expressed through Office. No initiative, contributions small. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made annual contributions: 1922-1930, $500; 1930-1932, $300; 1932-1936, $1,000. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur Young, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Council for Democracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mobilize and unify the minds of Americans in defense of democracy. Nelson A. Rockefeller interested but not active. Influential group of people. Appeal to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined. Council's activity and budget dwindled after war. John D. Rockefeller 3rd made $500 contribution in 1942. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., R. G. Swing, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Council for Democracy - John D. Rockefeller 3rd - Correspondence
Democracy - Subversive Activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Programs to save America, anti-Red, anti-Nazi. Many shades of political opinion. Rockefeller office consistently shied away from expressing an opinion regarding the several plans promoted. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined request to talk with Madame Chaing Kai Shek. Anti-Communist after end of WW II. No family interest or action. Many representatives of the lunatic fringe. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Dr. Harold Rugg - A. G. Rudd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Controversy over progressivism in schools. H. Rugg's textbook symbol of leftist tendencies. A. Rudd a defender of Americanism. Rugg and Columbia Teachers College associates. Rugg claims John D. Rockefeller, Jr. sponsorship through Lincoln School affiliation. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. asks Abraham Flexner for clarification. Rugg not financed by Rockefellers. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Citizenship Educational Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interdenominational group supporting democracy. Issued pamphlets against 5th Column. No Rockefeller interest. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Race Relations - Minorities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans and programs for the hiring relations presented to the Rockefellers. Winthrop Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller take forthright position. Negro, Jew are center of attention. Descriptions of betterment work by civil rights groups. Appeals for aid or interest usually declined. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Winthrop Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dana S. Creel, David Freeman, Warren Lindquist.

scopecontent.p: Clippings reporting progress of programs. New York and Washington D.C. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. attitude in radio speech. Nelson A. Rockefeller made single contribution to National Committee supporting Federal legislation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Frank Jamieson.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Common Council for American Unity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Merged with American Federation of International Institute to become American Council for Nationalities Service. To improve understanding between groups of Americans. Improve lot of immigrants. Encourage naturalization. Rockefeller Brothers Fund sent contributions. No interest shown by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Letters from Americans Campaign. Winthrop Rockefeller gifts, 1948-1953, $56,000. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, Winthrop Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Democracy - Friends of Democracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Created to arouse Americans to uphold the constitution and protect Democracy. Pointed out the evil of the Gestapo. After war kept on guard against native Fascists. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Highways - Roadside Development - Billboards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's interest in beautifying roadsides. Campaigns in Virginia, New York. Since oil companies were the most obvious offenders, the Rockefellers were frequently called on for action. Laurance S. Rockefeller leads in legislative contest in New York. Shows family's interest in pure beauty. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Robert Moses.

Pocantico Hills Lyceum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relations between Lyceum and churches. Providing recreation for the young men. Much community interest. Annual gifts by John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Small amounts given through J. H. Nelson. Building converted into fire house, 1934. Fourth of July fireworks. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. leases land. Correspondents include J. H. Nelson, S. H. Bent, J. Hughes, F. J. Heaney, Charles O. Heydt, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Hope Chapel, Community House, Tarrytown
Hope Chapel Community House, Tarrytown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presbyterian, but interdenominational in activities. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. makes pledge of $5,000 for Activity house; plans fell through. He gives $25,000 for Community house on smaller site, became Hope Presbyterian Church. Suffered from depression. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Willard S. Richardson.

did.unittitle: Political Organizations
Political Organizations - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Surge of appeals for aid during each presidential campaign. Consistent Rockefeller referral to policy of giving only to Republican Committees. Declined requests for campaign assistance. Plans and programs for defeating Franklin D. Roosevelt. No real interest shown by Office to 1949. 1928 Campaign requests for financial aid from various candidates. Suggestion that John D. Rockefeller, Jr. run for New York mayor in 1929. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. on Dwight D. Eisenhower. Material from the "lunatic fringe." Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel, Dana S. Creel.

did.unittitle: Political Organizations - United Republican Finance Committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purpose was to rebuild the Republican organization and to collect for State, County and National Committees. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. discusses New Deal with Winthrop Aldrich and with John D. Rockefeller, Sr. Rockefeller contributions 1935 and 1937. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., W. Aldrich.

did.unittitle: Political Situations - John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Thomas M. Debevoise Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on the New Deal by Thomas M. Debevoise and his acquaintances. Comments by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. on affairs of the nation. Discussion of repeal of 18th Amendment. Thomas M. Debevoise support of Hoover. Comments on Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal. Support for Wendell Willkie. Effect of Hatch Act on John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s political contributions. Appeals for political contributions declined. Thomas M. Debevoise handled John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s contributions. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s best wishes to Harry S. Truman. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. followed Citizens Union Voters Directory in voting for local candidates. No contributions to primary campaigns. Generally contributions made only to regular committees. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Thomas M. Debevoise, John E. Lockwood.

Research - Institute for Government Research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promote efficiency in government. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. $10,000 gift in 1918, 5 year pledge made in 1921, additional publication fund gift made in 1923. Primary interest in budgetary reform, history of Institute. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, Raymond B. Fosdick, Jerome D. Greene.

did.unittitle: Research - Institute for Government Research - Bureau of Public Personnel Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sponsored by National Research Council, United States Civil Service, etc. 1922 pledge by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. of $25,000 a year for 3 years. Gift renewed in 1925 for one year, modified to a three year pledge in 1926, renewed for one year in 1928. First contributions were made through Institute, later ones made directly to Bureau. Correspondents include Arthur Woods, Beardsley Ruml, William Gorham Rice.

did.unittitle: Tarrytown Projects - Tarrytown School - Consolidation Survey

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Move to consolidate schools in Pocantico Hills, Elmsford, Irvington and Tarrytown. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made several offers to assist in building new schools. Local politics kept things unhinged. No resolution in this file. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Tarrytown Projects - Tarrytown School Site

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. offers up to $300,000 to purchase site for new consolidated schools. Issue blocked by local groups. Discussed for four years. School board won final victory for consolidation, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. pledge called. Schools built. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., W. J. Yates.

did.unittitle: United States Government
United States Government - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller's interest in WPA art project. Roosevelt asks his support. Nelson A. Rockefeller in State Department in 1942. Universal registration, activity in war effort, propaganda, morale Organizations, OPA, correspondence. Dean Rusk accepting Trusteeship in Rockefeller Foundation. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. supports Dean Acheson's foreign policy. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s opinions on appeasement and the Korean War. John D. Rockefeller 3rd attends State Department meeting of Foundation executives interested in overseas work. Laurance S. Rockefeller gives $3,000 to study of Federal Government employees. Papers on tariffs, agriculture, foreign policy. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's interest in United States Information Agency. Requests for Rockefeller support of Administration policy. Eisenhower's request for Rockefeller support of Mutual Security Program. Refugees. International Conference. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Cordell Hull, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Dean Rusk, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Dana S. Creel, Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Westchester County Charter

Rockefeller, Jr., Kenneth Chorley, Starr J. Murphy, V. E. Macy, O. G. Cartright, J. Allen.

scopecontent.p: Program to cut expenses and taxes. Nelson A. Rockefeller refuses invitation to become director. Family withholds support because of possibility of adverse reactions. Association criticized by several segments of the population. Later called Civic League of Westchester. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Robert W. Gumbel, E. M. Allen.
